cab.content: CONFIDENTIAL LIBRARY;(This document is the property of His Britannic Majesty'a Government.)CABINET. HOME AFFAIRS COMMITTEE. WILD BIRDS BILL. Memorandum by the Home Secretary.This Bill was -introduced in the Commons last Session but made no progress. It is a consolidating and" amending measure based upon the Report of a Departmental Committee of 1919 and upon subsequent suggestions from the Wild Birds Advisory Committee. The existing law is inadequate and unsatisfactory in many respects and this is a non-Party Bill to whioh a great deal of thought has "been given by Lord Grey of Fallodon; the Chairman of the Advisory Committee, and others who are interested in this special subject. - Such criticisms' of the Bill as have reached me have been on points of detail and do not affect the main provision. I understand that certain-of the provisions of the Bill would be welcomed by the farmers. I should be glad if time could be found for the Bill, and it might be included amongst the Bills to be introduced in the House of Lords.: W.J.H.SECRET," CP. 45 (26).5th February, 192S. Wild Birds Protection Bill.ARRANGEMENT OE CLAUSES.General Protection of Birds.Clause.1. Prohibition of certain methods of talcing birds and of taking of birds on Sunday.2. Taking of birds for sale alive.3. Liberation of imported birds.Protection of Birds according to Categories.4i. Classification of birds for purposes of Act.5. Respects in which birds protected according to categories.6. Special provisions with respect to the lapwing. 7. Licences to kill and take birds, &c. 8. Register to he kept by taxidermists. 9. Creation of bird sanctuaries.Offences, Penalties and Legal Proceedings.10. Offences.11. Penalties.12. Legal proceedings.Supplementary Provisions. 13. Wild Birds Advisory Committee. 1L Orders of Secretary of State. 15. Powers and duties of constables. 16. Duties and expenses of local authorities. 17. Definitions. 18. Application to Scotland.19. Short title, extent, commencement and repeal. Schedules.30-1A [16 Geo. 5.]Wild Birds Protection.drafts aBILLtoRepeal the enactments providing for the protec- a.d. 1926. tion of Wild Birds and to substitute other provisions therefor.BE it enacted by the King's most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, 5 as follows : General Protection of Birds.1. It shall not be lawful for any person Prohibition(a) to affix, place or set on any pole, tree, or cairn "^j^"'^ of stones or earth, any spring, trap, gin or "aking birds 10 - other similar instrument calculated to cause and of takingbodily injury to any bird coming in contact of birds on therewith; or ' Sunday.(J)) knowingly to permit or suffer or cause any such instrument to be so affixed, placed, or 15 set; or(c) to take or attempt to take any bird by meansof a hook or other similar instrument; or(d) to use for the purpose of killing or taking birds any mechanically propelled boat or any20 aircraft; or(e) to kill or take, or attempt to kill or take, any bird on Sunday, except for the purpose of protecting property, crops, game or fisheries from immediate damage.30-1 A 2 2Wild Birds Protection.[16 Geo. 5.]A.I). 1926. 2. (T) It shall not he lawful for any person to take -TakiiT"ot any ^*rc^ ^or ^he PurPQse of sale alive unless he holds a bird "fop certificate granted under this section authorising him-to,sale alive. do SO :Provided that no certificate granted under this section 5 shall (a) authorise the taking in any highway or public place, or on any common, of any bird for the purpose of sale alive; or(b) be deemed to authorise the holder thereof to kill 10 or take any bird in contravention of any of the provisions of this Act.(2) A certificate authorising the taking of birds for the purpose of sale alive may be granted by the chief officer of police of the district in which the applicant for 15 the certificate resides, and any such certificate shall remain in force until the first day of March next ensuing after it is'granted, but maybe renewed for a year, and so from time to time. Any certificate so granted shall be available only in the police district in which it is granted, but may 20 be endorsed by the chief officer of police of any other police district so as to be available in that district.(3) An application for a certificate or for the renewal or endorsement of a certificate granted under this section shall not be refused unless the applicant has been convicted 25 of an offence which in the opinion of the chief officer of police renders him unfit to hold a licence.(4) There shall be payable on the grant of a certificate under this section such fee not exceeding five shillings, or on the renewal or endorsement of a certificate not exceeding 30 one shilling, as the Secretary of State may prescribe.Liberation of 8. It shall not he lawful for any person without imported the leave of the Secretary of State knowingly to liberate birds. imported birds of any species.Protection of Birds according to Categories. 35Classifica- 4. Subject as hereinafter provided, for the purposestion of 0f tnis Act the birds specified in Part I. and in Part II.Purposes of of the First Schedule to this Act shall be classifiedAdt. respectively .as being in Category I. and in Category II., [16 Geo. 5.] Wild Birds Protection. 3and all other birds shall be classified as being in 1926. Category III.; and references in this Act to those Categories shall be construed accordingly :Provided that the Secretary of State may, subject 5 to the provisions of this Act relating to the making of orders, by order alter the classification of any bird from one category to another, and on the making of any such order this Act shall have effect accordingly.5. (1) Subject to the provisions of this Act, it Respects in 10 shall not be lawful for any person which birds(a) to kill, injure or take, or to attempt to kill or according (o take, or to use any means for the purpose of categories, killing or taking, any bird at a time when it is protected; or15 (b) except in the ordinary course of farming or forestry operations to take or knowingly and wilfully to disturb any nest or egg at a time when it is protected; or(c) to sell, or expose or offer for sale, or to have in 20 his control or possession, any bird, or the skin orplumage or any part of any bird killed or taken, or any egg or nest taken, in contravention of this section:Provided that as respects any bird classified under 25 this Act as being in Category III., the foregoing pro-visions of paragraphs (a) and (6) of this section shall not apply to the owner or occupier of any land upon which any such bird is for the time being, or to any person belonging to his household or in his service, or authorised, 30- in writing signed by him to act on his behalf.(2) Por the purposes of this section (a) birds classified under this Act as being in category I. and the nests and eggs of such birds shall be deemed to be protected at all 35 times; and(b) birds classified under this Act as being in category II. and (subject to the special pro-visions of this Act relating to the lapwing) the nests and eggs of such birds shall he 30 . A 3 4Wild Birds Protection.[16 Geo. 5.]A.D. 1926.Special pro-visions with respect to the lapwing.Licences to kill and take birds, &c.deemed to be protected during the close season; and(c) birds classified under this Act as being in Category III. shall he deemed to be protected during the close season, but the nests and eggs 5 of such birds shall not he deemed, to be protected.6. (1) The provisions of the last foregoing section shall, as respects the nests and eggs of the lapwing, apply to the owner or occupier of any land upon which 10 any such nest or egg is found, or to any person belonging to his household or in his service, or authorised in writing signed by him to act on his behalf, as if the nests and eggs of the lapwing were not protected before the fifteenth day of April in any year. 15(2) During the period elapsing between the fifteenth day of March and the eleventh day of August, both days being included, in any year, it shall not be lawful for any person to sell for. human consumption or to have in his possession for the purpose of sale for human consumption 20 any lapwing.(3) On and after the twentieth day of April in any year, it shall not be lawful for any person to sell for human consumption or to have in his possession for the purpose of sale for human consumption any eggs of the lapwing. 257. (1) The Secretary of State shall, subject to the provisions of this Act, have power to grant a licence to any person for any scientific purpose or for the purpose of the protection of property, crops or fisheries, or for any other special purpose approved by him, 30 exempting the holder of the licence from any of the pro-visions of this Act relating to the killing or taking of birds of any category, or to the taking or disturbing of the nests or eggs of birds of any category.(2) Any applicant for a licence under this section 35 may he required to enter into a bond with or without sureties for the payment of a sum not exceeding fifty pounds in case any condition attached to the licence is infringed.(3), A licence under this section may be granted for 40 such areas, and subject to such conditions as may be specified in the licence. [16 Geo. 5.]Wild Birds Protection.5(4) There shall be payable on the grant of a licence A.D. 1926. under this section such fee not exceeding one pound as the Secretary of State may prescribe.(5) The Secretary of State shall furnish to the local 5 authority for any area in respect of which or any part of which a licence under this section is operative, particulars with respect to the licence, and the local authority shall cause a list of such particulars to be kept at their principal office, and the list shall be open to inspection at all 10 reasonable hours by any person on payment of a fee not exceeding one shilling.(6) A licence under this section may be signed either by the Secretary of State "or by any person authorised by him in that behalf.15 8. (1) It shall be the duty of every person carrying Register to on business as a taxidermist, or otherwise as a dealer in be kept by stuffed birds, or the eggs of birds, to keep a register of all taxidermists birds classified under this Act as being in Categories I. and II., and of the skins, eggs and nests of all such birds,20 received by him after the passing of this Act, showing details'in each case of the locality where they were taken and of the person from whom they were procured.(2) A register kept under this section shall be open to inspection at all reasonable times by any officer of 25 police or any person duly authorised by the local authority.9. (1) With a view to the creation of bird Creation sanctuaries the Secretary of State may, subject to the ^bird provisions of this Act relating to the making of orders, by 30 order direct that in any district defined by the order all birds, with or without any specified exceptions, shall in that district be deemed to be classified as being.- in Category I, and on the making of any such order this Act shall in that district have effect accordingly :35 Provided that no such order shall be made except with the consent of the owner and occupier of any land comprised in the district to which the order relates.(2) Any order made under this section shall provide for the classification of any birds excepted by the order 40 from classification in Category I. 30 A 4sanctuaries. 6 Wild Birds Protection. [16 Geo. 5.]A.D. 1926. ^ (3) The provisions of this section shall be without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing provisions of this Act empowering the Secretary of State to alter the classification of any bird.Offences, Penalties and Legal Proceedings. 5Offences. 10. Subject to the provisions of this Act anyperson who (a) commits any act declared by this Act to be unlawful; or(b) being a person in whose case a certificate or 10 licence granted under this Act has been revokedor cancelled applies for a new certificate or licence and conceals the fact that his certificate or licence has been so revoked or cancelled ; or(c) during any period in which a certificate or 15 licence granted under this Act to him is suspended, applies for a new certificate or licence and conceals the fact that his certificateor licence has been so suspended; or(d) being a person carrying on business as a taxi- 20 dermist or otherwise as a dealer in stuffed birdsor the eggs of birds, fails to keep a register in pursuance of the provisions of this Act, or makes in any such register an entry which is false in any particular, or refuses to submit any 25 such register for the inspection of any officer or person entitled under this Act to inspect it; or(e) being the holder of a licence granted under this Act infringes any of the conditions attached to the licence; 30shall he guilty of an offence against this Act.Penalties. H* CO person guilty of any offence against this Act shall he liable on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding five pounds, or in the case of a second or subsequent offence to a fine not exceeding ten pounds, 35 or to imprisonment for a period not exceeding one month.(2) Where an offence under this Act is in respect of more than one bird which is classified under this Act as being in Category I. or in Category II., or in respect of more than one egg or nest of any such bird, the fines 40 prescribed by this Act may be increased in proportion A.D. 1926. to the number of birds, eggs, or nests, in respect of which the offence was committed.(3) In addition to any other penalty which a court 5 has power to inflict for offences against this Act the court before which a person is convicted of any such offence may order that any bird, nest, or egg, in respect of which the offence was committed shall be forfeited, and, if they think fit, deposited in a public10 museum, and may order that any gun or other instru-ment in respect of or by means of which the offence was committed shall be, forfeited or otherwise dealt with as the court may direct, and may also order that any certificate or licence under this Act, held by the person15 convicted, shall be cancelled, or shall be suspended for such period as may be specified in the order, and where any certificate or licence under this Act has been so cancelled, or during any period when a certificate or licence is so suspended, no other certificate or licence20 granted under this Act to that person shall be valid.:'- (4) Upon the conviction of the holder of a licence granted under this Act for the offence of infringing any of the conditions attached to the licence the court shall, in addition to any other penalty which it has power to25 inflict, have power to enforce any bond entered into in accordance with the provisions of this Act as though it - were a recognizance, and the Secretary of State shall have poA^er to revoke the licence.12. (1) Where any person sells or has in his posses- Legal pro-30 sion for purposes of sale any bird, or the plumage or skin ceedings.:or any part of any bird classified under this Act as being in Category I., or the nest or egg of any bird, classified under this Act as being in Category I. or Category II., it shall, unless he satisfies the court before which any pro-35 ceedings are taken in respect thereof, that it was not, or that he had reasonable grounds for believing that it was : not so killed or taken, be deemed to have been killed or taken as the case may be in contravention of this Act.(2) Where any person is found in possession of any40 bird, or the plumage or skin or any part of any bird or the nest or egg of any bird, and it appears to the court before which any proceedings are taken in respect thereof that there is reasonable ground for believing that the bird, nest or egg was killed or taken at a time when it30 A 5 A.D. 1926. was protected under this Act, the bird, nest or egg, as the case may be, shall, unless the person against whom the proceedings are taken satisfies the court that it was not, or that he had reasonable grounds for believing that it was not so killed or taken, be deemed to have been killed 5 or taken in contravention of this Act (a) in the case of a bird classified under this Act as being in Category I., or the nest or egg of a bird classified under this Act as being in Category I.or Category II., if it is so found at any time: IX)(b) in the case of a bird classified under this Act as being in Category II., if it is so found on any day between the fifteenth day after the beginning and the last day of the close season for that bird, both days being included: 15(c) in the case of a bird classified under this Actas being in Category III., if it is so found during such period in the possession of any person not being the owner or occupier of the land on ' which the bird was killed or taken or a person 20 belonging to his household, or in his service, or authorised in writing signed by him to act on his behalf.(3) In any proceedings under this Act, the doing of any act which may be done under a certificate or licence 2d granted under this Act or by leave of the Secretary of State shall be deemed to have been done under such certificate or licence or by such leave, if the person who did the act proves that he was the holder of a certificate or licence issued under this Act or that he has obtained 30 the leave of the Secretary of State, as the case may be, authorising the doing of the act in question, but not otherwise.(4) All offences under this Act committed within the jurisdiction of the Admiralty shall be deemed to be 35 offences of the same nature, and shall render the offender liable to the same punishments,, as if they had been committed upon any land in Great Britain, and may be tried in any county or place in Great Britain in which the offender may be apprehended or be in custody 40 or be summoned, in the same manner in all respects as if such offences had been actually committed in that county or place ; and in any information or con- AD. 1926. viction for any" such offence the offence may he averred to have been committed " on the high seas."(5) "Where any offence under this Act is committed 5 in or upon any waters forming the boundary between any two counties or petty sessional districts such offence may be prosecuted before any justices of the peace in either of such counties or districts.(6) Charges for any offences against this Act may 10 be joined in the same information, if those charges are founded on the same ,facts, or form or are part of a series of offences of the same or a similar character.Supplemental Provisions.13. (1) There shall be established a Wild Birds Wild birds 15 Advisory Committee consisting of such members as may advisory be appointed by the. Secretary of State. committee.(2) The duties of the Committee shall be to advise the Secretary of State upon any questions which he may refer to the Committee in connection with the admini-20 stration of this Act, or with projected schemes for the protection of wild birds, either in Great Britain or internationally.14. (1) Subject to the provisions of this Act, orders Orders of made under this Act by the Secretary of State may be so Secretary 25 made as to apply generally or as respects any district of State-specified in the order, but no order shall be made so as to apply only to a district except on the application of, or after consultation with, the local authority for every area within the district to which the order relates.30 (2) At least one month before making under this Act any order which is to apply generally, the Secretary of State shall cause notice of the proposal to make the order and of the purport thereof to be published in the London Gazette and in' such other manner as appears to35 him to be desirable, and shall consider any objections to the proposal made within such time as may be prescribed in the notice.15. (1) Section forty-three of the Diseases of Powers and Animals Act, 1894 (which relates to the duties and d"*^ jfeiS 40 authorities of constables), shall as set out with modifi- con cations in the Second Schedule to this Act apply to this A. D. 1926. Act and to offences thereunder as if it were herein re-enacted.(2) A constable shall, if he has reasonable cause to suspect that any contravention of the provisions of paragraphs (a), (b), (c) or (d) of section one of this Act is being or is about to be committed on any land or premises, have power to enter on the land or premises without the consent of the occupier.Duties and expenses of local autho-rities.Definitions.16. (1) Every local authority shall cause to be kept exhibited in such manner and such consolidated form as the Secretary of State may direct, a summary of the provisions of this Act and of any orders affecting the area of the authority, at or in the immediate vicinity of all public elementary schools and police stations in the said area and at such other places as may appear to the local authority to be suitable with a view to bringing the contents thereof to the notice of the public, and shall also cause the said summary to he kept exhibited in any place which the Secretary of State may direct.(2) Any expenses incurred by a local authority under this Act shall be defrayed, in the case of the council of; a county as expenses for general county purposes, and in the case of the council, of a county borough out of the borough fund or borough rate.101520253017. In this Act unless the context otherwise requires, the following expressions have the meanings hereby assigned to them respectively, that is to say :-"Bird" means any wild bird except grouse, part-ridges, pheasants, and black game ;" Chief officer of police " has the meaning assigned to it by the Police Act, 1890, and with respect to the City of London means the Commissioner of the City Police ;" Close season" means in the case of the wood-cock the period elapsing between the first day 35 of Eehruary and the thirty-first day of August, both days being included, and in all other cases means the period elapsing between the first day of March and the eleventh day of August, both days being included :Provided that the Secretary of State may, subject to the provisions of this Act relating to40 the making of orders, by order extend, curtail, A.D. 1926. or otherwise vary, the close season, either for all birds or for any birds specified in the order; " Common " includes any land subject to being 5 enclosed under the Inclosure Acts, 1845 to1882, and any town or village green, and ' any other land subject to any right of common;" Highway " includes any public bridge, road, lane, or footway, whether a thoroughfare or not;10 " Local authority " means the council of a county or county borough ;" Police district " means any district for which there is a separate police force ;"Public place" includes any public park, garden, 15 or sea beach, and any ground to which thepublic for the time being have or are permitted to have access, whether on payment or other-wise.18. This Act shall apply to Scotland subject to Application 20 the following modifications : t0 Scotland.(a) there shall be substituted for references to " the Secretary of State," a reference to " the " Secretary for Scotland " ;" the "Wild Birds Advisory Committee," a reference 25 to " the Wild Birds Advisory Committee for" Scotland";"the Police Act, 1890," a reference to "the" Police (Scotland) Act, 1890 " ; " the London Gazette," a reference to " the 30 " Edinburgh Gazette ";"a county borough," a reference to "a burgh" being a county of a city " ; " a borough fund or borough rate," a reference to " such rate leviable within the burgh as 35 " the town council may appoint";" a public elementary school" a reference to" a public school"; " a surety," a reference to " a cautioner " ; " a recognizance," a reference to " a bond of 40 caution ";" an information," a reference to " a complaint ": A.D. 1926. (b) subsections (5) and (6) of section twelve shall not apply:(c) the expression " bird" shall not include the ptarmigan:(d) in the Island of St. Kilda this Act shall have 5effect as if the St. Kilda wren were classified as being in Category I, and as if the fulmar petrel were classified as being in Category III.Short title, 19. (1) This Act may be cited as the Wild Birdsextent, Protection Act, 1925. 10ment^nd6 (2) This Act shall not apply to Northern Ireland.repeal. (3) This Act shall come into operation on theday of , nineteen hundred and(4) The enactments referred to in the Third Scheduleto this Act are hereby repealed to the extent specified in 15the third column of that schedule. SCHEDULES.A.D. 1926.FIRST SCHEDULE.Section 4.Classification op Rirds. Part I.5 Birds in Category I.Avocet.Bearded Titmouse. Bee-eater.Bittern (all species). 10 Black Redstart. Black-winged Stilt. Bustard.Buzzard (all species, including Honey Buzzard). 15 Chough.Greeted Titmouse.Dartford Warbler.Eagle (all species).Falcon (all species). 20 Golden Oriole.Harrier (all species).Hawk (all species except Kestrel and Sparrow Hawk).(protected at all times).Hoopoe. Kentish Plover. Kite.Norfolk Plover.Owl (alL species except LittleOwl). Osprey.Phalarope (both species).Raven.Sand-Grouse.Shrike (all species).Spoonbill.Waxwing.Woodlark.Woodpecker (all speciesbPart II.25 Birds in Category II. (specially protected during the close season).Black-tailed Godwit. Capercaillie. Cirl Bunting. 30 Crake (all species). Crossbill.Diver (Black-throated and Red-throated). Dotterel. 35 Wild Duck (all species). Forked-tailed Petrel. Fulmar Petrel. Goldfinch.Grebe (all species except Dab-40 cluck). Greenshank. Kingfisher..Lapwing. Marsh Warbler. Nightingale. Pied Flycatcher. Quail.Rail (all species). Ruff and Reeve. Siskin.Skuas (all species). Snipe'(all species). Snow Bunting. Swan (all species). ' Tern (all species). Whimbrel.Wild Goose (all species). Woodcock. a.d. 1926.SECOND SCHEDULE.Section 15.Provisions op Section 43 op the Diseases op Animals Act, 1894, applied with Modifications.(1) Tie police force of each, police area shall execute and enforce this Act and every order of the Secretary of State 5 thereunder.(2) Where a person is seen or found committing, or is reasonably suspected of being engaged in committing, an offence against this Act, a constable may without warrant, stop, detain, and search him, and if his name and address are not 10 known to the constable, and such person fails to give them to the satisfaction of the constable, the constable may, without warrant, apprehend him ; and the constable may, whether so topping or detaining or apprehending the person or not, detain, and examine any bird, nest, egg, gun, or other instrument, 15 vehicle, boat, or thing to which the offence or suspected offence relates, and may seize and, pending prosecution, retain any such bird, nest or egg.(3) If any person obstructs or impedes or assists to obstruct or impede a constable or other officer in the execution of his 20 duty under this Act or under an order of the Secretary of State, the constable or officer may without warrant apprehend the offender.(4) A person apprehended under this section shall be taken with all practicable speed before a justice, and shall not 25 be detained without a warrant longer than is necessary for that purpose, and all enactments relating to the release of persons on recognizances taken by an officer of police or a constable shall apply in the case of a person apprehended under this section. 30(5) The foregoing provisions respecting a constable extend and apply to any person called by a constable to his assistance.(6) A constable shall forthwith make a report in writing to his superior officer of every ease in which he stops any person, animal, vehicle, boat, or thing under this section, and of his 35 proceedings consequent thereon.(7) Nothing in this section shall take away or abridge any power or authority that a constable would have had - if this section had not been enacted. THIRD SCHEDULE.Session and Chapter.5 43 & 44 Viet, c. 35. 44 & 45 Viet.c. 51. 55 & 56 Viet. 10 c. 55.67 & 58 Viet.c. 24. 59 & 60 Viet, c. 56. 15 2 Edw. 7. c. 6204 Edw. 7. c. 4 4Edw. 7.c. 10 8Edw. 7.c. 11Enactments repealed.Short Title.The Wild Birds Protection Act, 1880.The Wild Birds Protection Act, 1881.The Sand-Grouse Protection Act, 1888.The Wild Birds Protection Act, 1894.The Wild Birds Protection Act, 1896.The Wild Birds Protection Act, 1902.The Wild Birds Protection Act, 1904.The Wild Birds Protection (St.Kilda) Act, 1904. Section 19. Wild Birds Protection.DRAFT op aB I L LTo repeal the enactments providing for the protection of Wild Birds and to substitute other provisions therefor.XIX. (1.)5th February 1926.30-1
